name: STAR WARS™ Empire at War - Gold Pack
description: Command or corrupt an entire galaxy in the definitive Star Wars strategy collection. It is a time of galactic civil war. Will you take up the reins of the Rebellion, assume control of the Empire, or rule the Star Wars Underworld?
minimum_requirements: Computer: 100% DirectX 9.0c compatible computer Processor: Intel Pentium III 1.0GHz or AMD Athlon 1.0 GHz OS: Windows XP SP3, Windows Vista SP2, Windows 7 RAM: 512 MB Graphics Card: 64 MB graphics card with Shader Model 2.0 support / ATI Radeon 9600 / NVIDIA 7200 / Intel 965 Sound Card: 100% DirectX 9.0c compatible PCI, USB, or Onboard Audio Device Internet: 56kbps or faster connection (required for multiplayer only)
recommended_requirements: Computer: 100% DirectX 9.0c compatible computer Processor: Intel Pentium Dual Core CPU OS: Windows XP SP3, Windows Vista SP2, Windows 7 RAM: 1 GB Graphics Card: 256 MB graphics card with Shader Model 3.0 support / ATI Radeon X1900 / NVIDIA 8600 Sound Card: 100% DirectX 9.0c compatible PCI, USB, or Onboard Audio Device Internet: 1.5Mb DSL/Cable connection (required for multiplayer only)

reviews.review_text: If you like Star Wars, buy it. If you like sci-fi stragedy games, buy it. If you like killing every rebel scum you come across with the combined power of the death star 2 and a SUPER star destroyer with an unfair amount of bombers at your command, BUY THE SH*T OUT OF IT. This is the best rebel scum killing simulator since Star Wars Galaxies. Even if you aren't good at stradegy games play easy as the empire and you will have the most fun you ever had killing rebel scum like anoying cockroaches mildly annoying your empire of unstoppable stardestroyers and at-ats. You can even take control of an entire planet using only stormtroopers and patrol frigates.

This game is my childhood. Multiplayer died after being out for 5 years, which was most of the fun, but the singleplayer is still worth the money.   EDIT: Since the may the 4th sale, the multiplayer is booming.  EDIT 2: Gamespy is shutting down later this week, which means that multiplayer shoouullddd be gone. Forever. Let's hope that this isnt' the case though. Even without multiplayer, the game is amazing.

As soon as I started this game up, I built the death star and brought that thing straight to Naboo.  10/10 would commit mass gungan genocide again

Star wars™ Empire at war.... Got to love it. This game has to be or was one of the most popular rts games. The graphics havent aged the best but the graphics are fine. The game nolonger supports online multiplayer as the servers are down... Gameplay is just another awesome thing. There are 3 gamemodes, landcapture, space battle, and last but not least: Landbattles. The gameplay is really well done as there are so many details. either you have, plants that spit poision, nebulas,threatful blizzards, erupting lava pits, and astriod fields... You can also play on plane no threat levels if you feel like it. sadly mods arnt really a thing on steam no workshop... I recommend this game is in every rts fan's library.  9/10 Would get infantry army squished by one rebel tank...

Such a gem, and stong mod community. If you think this game looks neat you will be blown away with full conversion mods to bring the entire clone wars saga, the old republic, thrawns revenge and every space and ground unit, hero and planet you can think of.... an absolute must for any starwars fan or the movies or expanded universe.

If you wish to get into strategy games then I would recomend starting here, it is a RTS strategy not like the Total War series which is a turn based strategy with many things such as polotics, but Star Wars Empire At War dosen't have any of that stuff. Its just a plain and simple game with hundreds of hours of fun and maybe more. It dosen't say I have that because I played it years ago not on steam. Of course you can either play as the evil Empire or the Rebels, I have to say I found it easier to play as the Empire compared to the Rebels, but when your the empire and you finally manage to buil the Death Star it is so amazing, its just like your in the movies but instead of watching it your controlling it :) If your a Sci-Fi fan, RTS/ strategy or a Star Wars fan I would recommed getting this game now, I would say it is worth the money because there are so many skirmishes you can play and depending on how you play the campaign can go on forever literally, I even built the biggest fleet with over 200 space craft and possibly more and my laptop was lagging due to the ammount of ships I had in the game lol.

A fantastic, well-developed, excellently made strategy game that is incredibly fun to play, and simultaneously challenging to a very customiseable degree.  The rebellion are annoying to fight against, with strong abilities to evade space fights and strike right at the ground, having the most number of heroes and the strongest collection of force users. Their space units aren't too shoddy either  The Zann consortium are a nice, interesting faction, able to corrupt planets to make invasions easier. they have the most credits of anyone, and are incredibly survivable compared to the other two factions, able to stick around through deviousness and stealth, like the rebels. They lack any particular strengths in terms of space or land, but their Droidekas and Canterous Tanks make excellent ground forces, and their Keildabe-class battlecruisers aren't too shoddy.  The Empire is glorious. Pilot the SUPER STAR DESTROYER Executor in climactic (and very one-sided) battles across the galaxy, exploding space stations and planets with the Death Star and being incredibly intimidating and awe-inspiring. The Empire, despite less population space in space, is clearly the winner in any machup, and on ground the formidable arsenal of AT-AT's, Stormtroopers, AT-AA, Sith, and repulsor tanks makes them nigh impossible to remove without heavy losses or superior tactics.  Empire at war is for anyone who has ever wanted to feel the sheer power of commanding thousands of units into space battle against thousands of other units. For the Empire!

might not be the best rts but its definatly a good star wars game command your armies to take over the galaxy pretty straight forward whats special about this is you got two forms of combat, land and space which really makes capturing a planet a process since you have to get both to have full control of the planet,though you can send smaller units, particularly heros and you wont have to deal with the space battle units are broken up into infantry\fighters, light vehicles\small ships, artillary (or what would be called glass cannons), heavy vehicles\big ships and heros  heros are pretty self explanetory, the characters you know can fight on ground battles and some in space, alot of them can land on planets undetected and have special abilities, once a hero dies they will recharge before they can be brought back in again in the galactic modes you can build structures on planets that allow you to build units, get upgrades, etc every planet can build a space station which like some ground stuctures provides free garrison units when the planet is attacked ships and space stations are build up of hard points, hard points normally contain various types of turrets, shields, hangers, engines and special weapons, i thought this was really cool considering you can focus your forces on the most important hard point similar to how you attack the enemy ships engines, bridge, communication and life support in star wars battlefront 2 however these hardpoints contributes to the ships fuction and if they are destroyed they are gone for the rest of the battle (ex your engines are destroyed you go really slow, your shields are destroyed you have no shields)  one of the things that i disliked about the game is that you can auto result a battle which will automaticly complete the battle and show you the results the only problem is it decreases your winning chances signifgantly, auto battle is only a viable option when you want to give up a planet but want to take some forces with you but sometimes it wont even do that and if you do win you will get signifigant loses some units arent even properly balanced another thing is that the galatic conquests maps are always so split apart i enjoy the mode the most when you start off on less than 6 planets and have to beef up your defenses before going on the offenses, the problem is either your planets are two and far apart or you have too many planets and not nearly enough time or money to prepare your planets  i wish there where more galactic conquests though because skrimish is well skrimish and campagin is obviously very directed but then again you can always download custom ones so thats not a big deal i highly suggest getting the republic at war mod it really adds alot all and all its a enjoyable rts but not perfect
10/10 I wrote a review.

Being a fan of all six movies as well as some expanded universe material, I find the game to be great. It feature planets from both orginal and preaquel trillogy as well as EU planets like Taris and Koribban. I like how you need to contstruct units prior to battle. The renforcment system makes it unique from most RTS games I've played. Plus, it reminds me how much I loved the galactic conquest mod from BF II. Overall, a must buy for SW fans new and old.

I was never a fan of the expansion faction but it did add a few cool things to the game. Overall a good buy for any Star Wars fans.

Star Wars + real time strategy + strategic gameplay? A winning combo in my humble opinion :P In addition to fighting real time battles over planets and in space, there is a campaign mode with a map where the player can plan which planet to attack, which production structures to build, and planetary defences. Planets have natives allied to the different sides that will help that side in any battle there (Rebellion/Empire/Zhan Consortion) and also provide unique bonuses for whoever controls them.  The bundle also comes with 3 full campaigns, the third culminating in the player controlling a Eclipse-class super star destroyer complete with it's very own anti-ship superlaser. Not to mention that the Empire can build the Death Star itself and use it to destroy enemy planets.  Also, X-wings, lightsabers, and Darth Vader.  Why don't you have this game? RATING: 9.5/10

7/10  I love this game so why 7/10? Let me tell you... Corruption!!! Why isn't there some kind of tech or what ever to help control this super annoying feature? Many fan boys have complained about this and yet nothing was ever done. Two: No one is faster than the computer so why can't the player start to move their units on the campaign map in pause or during the start of a battle? I find some times I go from battle to battle without being able to react to anything on the campaign map. Just give me 1/2 a second to move my units. Good Lord! And, this is a big one, multiplayer isn't supported anymore!!!! WTF!?!?  Well, that was my two cents. Oh and don't expect updates with any of Petroglyph or LucasArts' games. Won't ever happen because they don't think they make money from fixing released games. Yet they still sell them and at full price almost ***6 YEARS*** later! humm? Shame on you!! If they would fix these three things I could recommend getting this game at full price of $20 but they won't so get it on sale for under $10 or even $5.

Star Wars Empire at war is not what I expected. I bought this game hoping for a solid Star Wars RTS; however, I ended up sadly disappointed. The campaign mechanics are broken to the point where you can just form a blocade of a space fleet around planets, spam credits, then demolish the enemy fleets. Now with all of this being said I still enjoyed this game just for the Star Wars aspect of it. If you love Star Wars RTS games, or you are a Star Wars fan I do reccomend this game, but if you are a hardcore RTS player I do not reccomend this game Score:5-6/10

Having completed all three campaigns and one game of conquest my worst fears are confirmed. EAW is an RTS hybrid that tries to be many things but is tripped by technical issues, bad design decisions and a clear lack of testing. The end result is a game that is mediocre at best and only held together by the magic glue that is Star Wars. Only recommended for fans who are willing to suck on a lollypop made out of pure salt just because it's shaped like Darth Vader's helmet.   +Authentic Star Wars music and sound effects that leave nothing to be desired. Sometimes even the voice acting is surprisingly good +Graphics seem fairly timeless with some space battle effects still looking pretty sweet +Space battles are fun most of the time +Asymmetric factions (Empire has bigger ships with free fighters, Alliance has better fighters that require no carriers etc.) +Multiple campaigns and conquest mode scenarios +Dropping the screen filling Executor in the middle of a battle for the first time should make any nerds inner fascist climax immediately  -Doesn't seem to play nice with Win10 and has no borderless window support. If played fullscreen while Alt-Tabing can put your Windows in a state where you have to reboot to get anything done. I recommend running it in a maximized window instead. -Game breaking bugs include disappearing critical characters, inability to task units to campaign critical missions, disappearing units etc. These issues can be somewhat circumvented with furious saving.  Always save to a new file!  -A multitude of UX issues that range from fighters needlessly blocking capital ships from selection to the way save files are handled: latest saves don't always show up first, save files take too much space etc. -AI blatantly cheats both by its very nature and also seems to gain scripted fleets out of nowhere for the campaigns -AI sometimes just freezes and does nothing with its ships in battle -Unit AI is atrocious and does not seem to do any target prioritization whatsoever for any attacks. Pathfinding gets progressively worse with unit size to the point where units like AT-ATs, artillery units and Star Destroyers sometimes require near constant micromanaging so that they move the way you need -Being unable to assign any movement orders on the galactic map in pause mode makes no sense -Forces of Corruption doesn't integrate to the main game and is actually a separate game that feels like it was cheaply hacked together in a hurry -While the original EaW is somewhat balanced, the Consortium faction in FoC is completely out of whack and seems to have the best in almost everything in addition to their frustrating corruption mechanic that requires constant fiddling especially from the opponents -Ground battles are usually horrendously repetitive and tedious -Battles can be autoresolved, but the logic for resolving them is completely ludicrous and can lead to massive casualties even if the opponent doesn't actually have any chance of fighting back -Very limited amount of units and ships in a battle at any given time (for example, you can have 6 Imperial class Star Destroyers if you have almost nothing else) and the rest have to be drip-fed into the battle as reinforcements when previous units are destroyed -Player can't choose which units enter a battle first in EaW (mostly fixed in FoC though) -Flying units can't actually fly over many obstacles in ground battles -Some of the writing and voice acting is very cringeworthy especially in FoC. A few characters also use quotes from the movies to a ridiculous degree even for fanservice -The Alliance can commit genocide without any issues and can actually get more funds from it

TL:DR - If you're looking for a more casual RTS - This isn't it.  So, I can see how this would be something many people could like. It is Star Wars after all. But after playing for a good 5 hours, I can tell that this is not a Star Wars game that I like. Which is very rare for me.   My experience with it so far has been pretty horrendous, mainly through seemingly cheating AI mechanics and sudden difficulty spikes. Naturally, I was playing on Easy, and I'm not great at RTS, but I sort of assumed it would be more like C&C where you would have time to build up your forces and then assualt the enemy. Its not like that at all. My experiences come from C&C Red Alert and Generals and I've also played a fair amount of Shogun Total War. My issue I feel is that the time scale of the game literally leaves you behind within 30 seconds.   In Galactic CQ, I am frequently being raided and out-gunned within the first 5 minutes of play. The AI steam rolls as it doesn't seem to be confined to the amount of actions a human could physically decide upon and take. The AI is so precise and clinical in its processes, that within the first 5 Galactic days, the Rebellion already has amased an economy 5 times greater than my own. I've been through forums and such and there seems to be no real answers about why this game is so different in play style to C&C or Shogun. But I feel its the fact that the AI moves so fast.  Personally I was looking for a more casual Star Wars C&C clone. This is not what this game is, unless you're already good at such game. I feel like I would have enjoyed it more if I had time to learn and not be swept off the game board almost immeditly by huge fleets which can't physically have been created with only a starting credit cap if 5K. Inexperience is also a deciding factor. The tutorials are decent, but they don't really provide you with the load of how much you have to do and organise. Also, the reinforcement mechanic which the player is forced to use, but the AI can happily spawn tanks etc against you... is just broken.   Also, don't bother playing the expansion. The 3rd faction is so OP that there is literally no point, unless you like seeing all of your 'owned' worlds, completely corrupted and leeched within 30 seconds.  Just glad I bought it on sale. If we consider £1 for 1 hour of play-time, I'd say the game at least achieved that.

Sluggish controls, tactical map unit caps, and a real time macrostrategic map of the galaxy make this a pain. Yes, there's a pause button on the galactic map, but you can't do anything while paused like move fleets or build units. It only works on the tactical map. Also, some of the scenario maps seem glitched on tech levels. If you go to advanced settings and reduce the starting tech level while playing on hard, then you start with reduced technology but the computer starts with regular technology. Having X Wings, Y Wings, and basic frigates doesn't really match top of the line Imperial Star Destroyers.  There's also no hold position command. You can tell units to stop, but it's very easy to lure or get lured, especially when units won't respond instantly after being lured. This creates a very annoying situation where rocket infantry wreck light tanks, anti-infantry vehicles wreck light infantry, and aircraft become pointless (although aircraft dominate easily until AA weapons are around). In space, it means fighters and bombers won't withdraw from cruisers, and larger ships that are slightly misoriented beacuse they advanced two inches too far take forever to turn around.  The game really isn't that bad, but it's like they choked it for no good reason and ruined the experience. If the units were responsive, tactical map unit caps didn't exist, the galactic map was turn based instead of real time, and the pause button let you issue orders while paused, then this would be an easy thumbs up. I have no idea why they ruined their own game with arbitrary restrictions.

I've enjoyed Empire at War and especially the Forces of Corruption expansion pack since it was first released. When I found it on Steam, I rejoiced! My joy was short-lived when I discovered that the game I purchased was only the original game without the expansion pack.  I'm an avid customer of the Steam site, but this was disappointing. It goes to show that even when you read information closely, you can still get burned, even by a reputable company.

Game is RTS for dummies. Minimal strategy or control over your units in space combat. Galactic display tactics is extremely basic and overly simplistic. I actually enjoy playing Star Wars Rebellion over this game. Overall a poor effort.

For a game as old as this one it delivers on so many aspects, and with the modding community thats built up over the years this game is something everyone should definutely have in they're library. Its a simple strategy game where you pick your faction, manage your income(its not complex at all you get so many credits per second/day depending on what mode your playing--skirmish or a campaign), build the units you need, move whatever units, point being its all at your your control, upgrade your tech lvl to lvl 5 and conquer the galaxy or cream the AI in skirmish mode. Its all in real time but you can fast forward, pause, and play at your descretion at any time. Multiplayer is where the game just gets better, add some mods and hit repeat, this game only improves on itself. I can't wait to see any sort of sequel.   In conclusion, I've had years of fun with this game and its one of the best space RTS games available even today, theres a reason this game is on the top ten list of the best star wars games of all time.  Solid 10/10, if youre looking for any sort of game to pick up, this is well worth the money, especially whenever its on sale.

This game was a gem for me when i was younger, it was... it is still amazing, i really hope that there will be more Star Wars RTS games in the future.  Pros: +AT-ATs! +Almost every single (MILITARY) vehicle known to Star Wars and more! +Space combat is very fun, but so is ground. +NPCs on certain planets, ex: Tusken Raiders on Tatooine, will attack you. +Voice acting is great, Boba Fett sounds just like a Clone! (he is supposed to)  Cons: -AIs seem to cheat? Or gain troops faster, even though you are trying to build up. -Some units move strangely, can't do certain actions like move through a canyon on Hoth that clearly they could! -Only GOOD Star Wars RTS. (This could be positive, but it's negative because i want more of them) -The Add-On: Forces of Corruption didn't feel very complete/fulfilling.
Love it. Good graphics for its release year. Good set up and storylines. I definatly recommend to RPG/Star Wars lovers.

One of the best RTS games ever made and probably amongst the best Star Wars games, too.  In Empire at War, you'll have the option to command three factions (assuming you have the Gold Edition): The Galactic Empire, the Rebel Alliance and the Zann Consortium. Each faction has dozens of unique unities with unique habilities assinged to them. There are many modes of play available, including a campaing for each of the factions, the Galactic Conquest mode, which will have you using the best of your habilites to complete specific objectives in the galactic map and the well known skirmish mode. There is also, of course, multiplayer.  Graphics are great, sound effects are flawless, soundtrack lends from most of the original tracks from the trilogy of movies, so you can bet your ♥♥♥ there is going to be some great music playing while you blast your way through the galaxy with the Death Star at your side. All the characters you expect to see will be there plus a few more. Played this game pretty much in every possible way before I got bored back when it came out. Replayed it on Steam all these years later and it haven't aged a day, still had fun with it. If you're a fan of the genre, there is not much to think about. There might be a few flaws here and there, like the camera zoom being locked pretty closed and the actual amount of units permitted per battle being rather low, but this game is unbelievably good. Get it.   Gameplay - 7/10 Soundtrack - 10/10 Graphics - 7/10 Content - 8/10 Challenge Level - 8/10 Replayability - 8/10

It's awesome to warp into an unsuspecting star system with a fleet of Star Destroyers at your back and blast your enemies into space kibbles!  Or, as the tyrannical Empire, to figuratively AND literally trample the opposition with your mechanized walkers!  Or to watch your super high tech army get destroyed by hordes of Stone Age Ewoks!  Or to blow up freaking planets with the Death Star!  There are 3 official single player campaigns, a skirmish mode for one-shot fights, and a Conquest mode for waging a large scale military campaign across multiple worlds. Multiplayer is no longer supported however.  I rate this 9 out of 10, would conquer this galaxy again!

If you want to rule the Far, Far away Galaxy as either the Evil Galactic Empire, the Glorious Rebel Alliance, or the Corrupt Tyber Zann Consortium, you're on the right spot, this game is the best game you could have gotten to play a 4x on the universe of the Blasters and Light Sabres.  Pros: -Its fun to re-write the history of Star Wars, from killing important figures like Han Solo or Luke Skywalker, to conquering key planets like Coruscant or Kuat, and turning them into the largest possible Rebel bases. -The replayability factor of this game is almost limitless.  Cons: -The unit A.I. is a bit wonky, as this is an older game. -Sometimes, the Death Star cinematic of a planet's destructiion might crash the game.

If you're looking for a grand strategy to challenge the mind and exhaust the body, leave now. --- If you are still here, this game is a really fun, if simple, Star Wars RTS. The game lets you play as the Rebel  Alliance  Scum, or the  evil  Glorious Empire, and wage war against the other faction on a map covering all major planets from the Star Wars universe, and many lesser known worlds from the EU. If you've played an RTS before, you'll know what to expect, but if not, watch a youtube video. Pretty easy to understand.  Worth mentioning is that the Multiplayer hasn't worked since 2014, so if you want to play with someone else, you need to use something like GameRanger to make it think you are using a LAN, rather than being in seperate places. Of course, the singleplayer Galactic Conquest is excellent, and will keep you more than happy without multiplayer. If you find the game too easy (it is), or if you want a different setting, there are dozens of excellent mods for the game, from Clone Wars era to post-RoTJ Imperial Civil War. There's even a Knights of the Old Republic mod, but idk if it's any good.  Overall, I recommend it, but don't be suprised if the difficulty is a bit too low.

However, the difficulty curve from the first mission to the next is a little high, you go from a simple mission to a relatively difficult one, so be prepared and have some practice with another RTS under your belt.

This is a great game, the gameplay is well ballanced and it is very entertaining. Multi-player is not mutch good anymore but singleplayer is good and well worth the money. I highly recommend this to star wars fans, or any sci-fi fan, and RTS fans.

This game is awesome! There are some balance issues, I suppose, but that is just because different factions are better at different things. If you want to influence the Galactic setting and make tons of credits, all the while making it harder for your opponents to get things done, the Consortium is your bag. If you like units with nifty abillities to help you pull of tactical victories, the Rebellion will suit you just fine. And if you want to crush your enemies with sheer numbers and might, the Empire is the full frontal assault faction that you're looking for.  Over all, I wish that they'd make a new one, and the graphics are definitly from the early 2000's, but I still play the crap out of this game. A good buy for anyone who loves starwars and RTS games.

As a child this game was great and still is to me. The game is very fun, it feels like someone took Battlefront (another starwars game) and put it into a RTS. This version is also very good because it adds a third side to the war, the corruption, the bounty hunters. Plus the game has many differnt ground and space units for each faction. Also for large battles you can go into a battle cam which is amazing. It like watching a moive made in a video game. The one downside of the game is the ships noclipping in space battles but its still good for its time. 9.5/10

I first played Empire at War when I was 9 and I have been hooked ever since. Now I'm 15 and I am still loving it. Although I personally never get tired of Story Mode and Galactic Conquest Mode, I occasionally look up mods (this game has some of the best mods of all time, even if you don't have the DLC expansion pack) and I love those too. I usually compare this game to Halo Wars on Xbox 360. The gameplay is very similar to upgrading buildings and telling troops where to go on the battlefield, and the space combat is exactly the same. There is an out of battle part of the gameplay (unless playing Skirmish Mode) where you send fleets and troops to other planets to attack, reinforce, or retreat. You also train troops and build ships and space stations for when you actually fight in this part of the game. There are heroes in the game you can play as (Darth Vader, Boba Fett, Han Solo, Chewbacca, Luke Skywalker (Red Squadron in base game only, Jedi Knight in DLC only), Yoda, and more). This game was a gateway drug to strategy games for me and I was obviously attracted to it as a Star Wars fanboy, but this really did get me into strategy games. The only thing I might be worried about is the fanboy level in this game. If you are not a fanboy, this game is still worth trying, but you might get bored way too early.

Nearly a decade on and I am still finding new tricks.

6.9/10 +Vast array of unique units with their own uses +Galactic map +Land and space battles -Bad graphics -Too reliant on overpowered artillary  -Dumb friendly AI    This game is endearing. It may take itself a little bit too seriously, but it makes up for it in outlandish gameplay. You will play as the Rebels, or the Empire, in a battle for control of the galaxy. This game offers both a campain where you must fight on a galactic map, or skirmishes set on premade worlds.  You can take to both space, and land to fight the war. There are a ton of unique units to play with, everything from a snowspeeder, to an AT-AT, to a Rancor. The gameplay is basically a mix between king of the hill, and base destruction. WHile the game is fairly balanced, you will find that the enemy AI is extremely reliant on artillary forces, which can fire through the FoW, and essentially deal massave damage to anything it hits, which can be extremely frustrating when you have a ton of infantry or light vehicles grouped together.  All together, I would buy this when it is on sale. It is a nice game to pass time, and relive your old Star Wars fantasies.
Great Game buy it
Probably the best RTS in the Star Wars Universe. A must have!

Uncle Vader wants YOU!  One of the best Star Wars games for certain. And definitely the ultimate Star Wars RTS. Sure, the visuals may be dated and whatnot. But we get a Europa Universalis style strategic Galactic Conquest mode with the option to play real time battles. Then there's the fast paced Skirmish mode. Now, I don't really like the ground battles here just because space combat is so awesome it makes them seem redundant. A truly all-encompasing strategy with everything for a tactics or grand strategy freak.  So... Might as well hop in and crush the rebel scum and restore order in the Galaxy, don't you think?
An instant classic Starwars game the equivalent to a civ/age of empires mash-up

Empire at War is one of the few RTSs that has kept its appeal throughout the years without having to re-release or sequelize itself every few years. The land battles have a certain something about them that makes them enjoyable, but the space battles are what really attracts one to the game. A beautifully done piece of art serves as the background for most of the space arenas and the sprites are very well drawn/animated with a good level of detail. Ship movement is fluid, and the AI seems somewhat realistic in sticking with the tactics of their respective STAR WARS sides/teams. All in all, I would recommend this game if you are a fan of STAR WARS space battles, but I would recommend something more like Supreme Commander of Planetary Annihilation for someone in the mood for a good land battle-based RTS.
Great RTS game.

One of the greatest Star Wars games made in my opinion!   In the game you get to choose between play as the Rebel Alliance or Galatic Empire after the first Death Star as been completed and what faction you choose will determine the outcome the fate of the galaxy. Engage in awesome space battles, land skirmishes, and fortify your conquered planets to repel invanders!  In the expansion Forces of Corruption to take on the role of Tyber Zann, a infamous criminal who partnered with Jabba the Hutt but was betrayed, who seeks to rebuild his criminal empire after he escapes prison and takes his revenge on Jabb the Hutt. While your goal my not be the conquer the galaxy you instead can 'corrupt' planets by using your agents to preform activies like intimitation and bribery to spread your criminal empire throughout the galaxy!

Great game showing the tactical command of the fleets throughout the GCW Era. Never stops being fun for a Star Wars space battle addict.  Pros: - Great combat and tactics -Detailed ships and high variety of them -Lots of Mods for other eras.  Cons: - Not really, I play COD a lot but i still go back to this awesome game. ;P

Good game, alot of fun, also a bit of good and bad. Firstly the battles are very enjoyable, Sometimes the AI will scum you but you can do the same thing to the AI if you play correctly. One issue I have is with the republic campaign, it is centered around the time prior to the movie A New Hope and continues until the end of said movie. This very much disapoints me because content from the other two original movies would have made for an amazing campaign. I would have loved to fight the battle of Hoth, or blow up the Death Star a second time. Other then that, and the population limits on the battlefield I would say this is a good game; I have had hours of fun with it and I am sure any other Star Wars fan would also.

Empire at War is the last great RTS attached to the famed Star Wars name following in Galactic Battleground's and Force Commanders footsteps. Commanding either the Rebellion, Empire, or the Zann Consortium to take the battle to the ground and to space across the galaxy using iconic ships, vehicles and heros of the Empire and Rebellion as well as the new forces of the Consortium. As fun as this game is, its sorely lacking and will get boring relatively fast. That and the empire and rebellion are sorely missing a large number of their forces from the EU in the game as standard and most if not all of the models are rather under detailed. Thankfully EaW has(had) a very large modding community offering things from minor map packs to entire total conversions bringing you from the Jedi Civil War of KOTOR fame, to the Clone Wars, to the grimdark era of the late EU. If you track down any of these mods to help liven the game up then I fully recommend to play this. Even as stock this game is worth a shot. This game deserves a mention as one of the better Star Wars games. Check it out if your a RTS fan and if you like to mod.
Have you ever wanted to rule the Galaxy with Darth Vader and the mighty Imperial or try to save it with the daring Rebels, then this is the game for you!!!!  10/10 will play agian!!!!

This game looks like an Star Wars version of Age of Empires, I'm not saying it is, but reminds me of it. I haven't played a lot, but I already like it. Considering the age of this game I say that if you won't mind the ugly graphics it will be fun. 7/10

Probably the best, if not one of the best games I have ever played. It's kind of like a Star Wars version of a simplified CIV V. The Forces of Corruption 'Expansion Pack' (More of a sequel than an expansion pack) is also loads of fun. I'd recommend also installing the Republic at War mod, which is like the prequel/sequel of the original EaW that never was. Honestly, if EA updated the graphics and some of the mechanics/units, they could probably get away with reselling the game. If you have any interest in Star Wars, GET THIS GAME. EaW is also an amazing introductory game to the vast world of strategy games (Such as EU4, CIV V, etc.)
Solid 8/10. When you add Mods it makes this game a classic
tHIS GAME IS DANK

Very good game, overall wonderful, it gives endless fun of various possibilities and replications of battles from the movies from both sides, it is days and days of fun for just one of the runthroughs. Three things I would have liked that would have made it perfect; first, better support for ultrawides and/or multimonitor (I have an ultrawide and a 1080p monitor), the active image (everything but menues sans planets) get progressively more and more stretched out further you get from 16:9, I would have loved to see the battlefield using both my UW and standard seeing a platoon march from one side of one monitor, across it, then across my ultrawide to the edge of it, but it was basically unusable with the amount of stretching. Second thing is that I would have loved to see an expansion following the extended universe, I wanted so much to fight the battle of Byss and had a level destroying World Devistators plus battling the Kiss Empire (I know there was probably a mod for one of these, but still). The third and easiest change I would have loved would be for the standard runthrough for the Rebels would be following the Deathstar blowing up, retaking the galaxy and the Empire having further and further more sophisticated units and weapons while the user lags behind the advances, or not, just further pushing Empire into a ball that makes it more and more difficult to fight. Anyway, I know this is an older game and my three points are nit picking, it is an incredibly good game hands down, such a good game, do buy it

Star wars Empire at War is an amazing Star wars game. Star Wars Empire at War is probably one of the Top 10 Best Star Wars PC games. Besides the temporary lag (possibly because of the amount of blaster fire being shot in the game), this is an awesome game, also the video view is epic, especially in space battles. I truly have had a wonderful experience this game and I would recommend that other Star wars fans should play this game and also use the mods of which ever era u prefer to play (i.e: the clone wars mod) if you like them.

This game is awsome. It is old, but it's gold. I need to say that I'm using a mod called 'Thrawn's Revenge', which also made the graphics a bit better. However this game is from 2006 and still fun to play. That's what characterises a good game. It is still quite popular a decade after publishing. This is a game that truely earned my respect. Thumbs up to the creators and awsome modders who have been working on it for years and still keep going.

A msut play for people into the star wars lore and universe. The game has excellent space combat, but unfortunately suffers from mediocre ground combat. A small-moderate selection of units keeps the game interesting for a good 15 or so galactic conquests before becoming dull.   However the massive modding community fixes this by adding infinite hours of content, a huge selection of units and impovements to ground combat. Overall I reccomend it to anyone, especxially Star Wars fans, just be willing to download some mods if you want to keep the longevity of this game.
An excellent RTS with unique and fun ideas. Still holds up after a decade and mods work on the Steam version.
Game is 10 years old but it's still awesome. There are a lot of great mods for singleplayer and I enjoy the multiplayer campaign as well.
